bestBHT.bht: Jesus cursed a solitary fig tree by the roadside as a striking object lesson. This vivid act illustrated the barrenness and falsehood of Israel's religious pretensions. The curse symbolized the judgment that awaited false professors, emphasizing their lack of genuine holiness. Jesus, hungry for the salvation of humanity, approached the fig tree with hopes for fruitfulness, but found only empty words and empty religion. This fig tree served as a symbol of the Jews, highlighting their failure to bear the righteousness that should have flourished within them.

Henry Alford: It was the practice to plant fig-trees by the road-side, because it was thought that the dust, by absorbing the exuding sap, was conducive to the production of the fruit.
one fig tree, i.e. a solitary fig-tree.
Marvin Vincent: Presently, in popular speech, has acquired something of a future force.
The rendering here was correct in the older English sense of instantly.
So constantly in Shakspeare: 'Presently? Ay, with a twink.'
John Calvin: Let us learn from this what is the meaning of the word curse, namely, that the tree should be condemned to barrenness; as, on the other hand, God blesses, when by his voice he bestows fertility.
It appears more clearly from Mark, that the fig-tree did not instantly wither, or, at least, that it was not observed by his disciples, until they saw it next day stripped of leaves.
as Christ replies in the plural number, it may naturally be inferred that one put the question in the name of all.
Philip Schaff: The solitary tree was a figure of Israel set by itself; the leaves represented the hypocritical pretensions to sanctity, the barrenness the lack of real holiness."
A miracle of punishment, both a parable and prophecy in action: a 'parable,' teaching that false professors will be judged; a 'prophecy' in its particular application to the Jews.
The curse was for falsehood as well as barrenness. The true fruit of any people before the Incarnation would have been to own that they had no fruit, that without Christ they could do nothing.
Archibald T. Robertson: On you no fruit shall ever grow again" (Weymouth).
The double negative ου μη with the aorist subjunctive (or future indicative) is the strongest kind of negative prediction.
It was a vivid object lesson.
John Gill: Though it was 'afar off', as Mark says, yet being hungry, he made up to it, expecting, from its promising appearance, to find fruit on it.
This fig tree was 'in the way'; by the road side, and probably had no owner; was common to anybody, and so no injury was done to any person by losing it.

This tree was an emblem of the Jews: Christ being hungry, and very desirous of the salvation of men, came first to them, from whom... much fruit of righteousness might have been expected; but, alas! he found nothing but mere words, empty boasts, an outward show of religion.

bhtAttempts.bht: By cursing the barren fig tree, Jesus conveyed a powerful message. The fig tree, planted by the road, was a symbol of Israel's false sanctity and hypocritical claims. It was a vivid object lesson, demonstrating that false professors would face judgment. The curse represented not only barrenness but also falsehood, highlighting that without Christ, any people's fruit would be lacking. Jesus, hungry for the salvation of humanity, approached the fig tree expectantly, but it failed to produce any real fruit. This fig tree, representative of the Jews, displayed empty words and outward religious displays, highlighting their failure to bear the righteousness that should have flourished within them.

In Matthew 21:19, Jesus cursed a solitary fig tree by the roadside. This act served as a vivid lesson, illustrating the barrenness and falsehood of Israel's hypocritical pretensions. The curse symbolized the judgment awaiting false professors. Jesus, desiring the salvation of humanity, approached the fig tree with hope for righteousness, but it failed to produce any true fruit. This fig tree, representing the Jews, displayed empty words and outward religiosity, revealing their inability to bear the spiritual fruit they should have.

By cursing the solitary fig tree, Jesus provided a powerful object lesson about the barrenness and falsehood of Israel's religious facade. This act of judgment conveyed that false professors would face consequences. The fig tree, representing the Jews, showcased empty boasts and outward religiosity while failing to produce genuine fruit. Jesus, hungry for the salvation of humanity, found disappointment in the lack of righteousness. The curse served as a warning about the importance of true faith and genuine spiritual transformation.

Jesus cursed a solitary fig tree by the roadside as a striking object lesson. This vivid act illustrated the barrenness and falsehood of Israel's religious pretensions. The curse symbolized the judgment that awaited false professors, emphasizing their lack of genuine holiness. Jesus, hungry for the salvation of humanity, approached the fig tree with hopes for fruitfulness, but found only empty words and empty religion. This fig tree served as a symbol of the Jews, highlighting their failure to bear the righteousness that should have flourished within them.

Jesus' curse of the solitary fig tree alongside the road emphasized Israel's barrenness and false religiosity. This profound object lesson taught that false professors would face judgment. Through this symbolic act, Jesus conveyed the importance of genuine holiness and righteousness. Hungry for the spiritual fruit of salvation, Jesus approached the fig tree with anticipation, only to find empty words and hollow religious displays. This fig tree, representative of the Jews, revealed their failure to bear the fruits of righteousness that were expected of them.
